fields.Help Section 1 Text: This is the name of the customer. This cannot be changed.
Products are the goods or services you buy. If you buy subscriptions, you might call them "plans." Product names are usually non-unique and succinctly describe the product.
A product description briefly describes the use and purpose of a product.

Any order will contain multiple reference numbers, these can be Product Order (PO) numbers, Item Codes, codes from an ERP system etc.

The reference number entered here should be shared by both the supplier and customer, e.g. PO number.

Product images, bills of materials, CAD files or any other supporting documents help to improve the price prediction, categorisation and recommendation features of Axiom. We strongly recommend you upload all your supporting documents.
If your supplier is not on the list below then they have not been onboarded yet. Please go to the supplier tab to invite new suppliers.
The product quantity refers to the number of individual units ordered. E.g. If 10,000 brochures are ordered then the quantity is 10,000 even if they are packed into boxes of 50 brochures.
The date on which the order was placed with the supplier.
The date on which the order was delivered. If multiple shipments arrived on different days, select the earliest date.
This is the final cost price paid by the customer.
Many organisations will name or categorise their product types slightly differently. Even if the name differes slightly (e.g. leaflet vs pamphlet) please select the closest functional match.

This is the number of pages in the item, 1 piece of paper has two sides and so is 2pp, please count the pages even if they are not printed on. 

If the item has a cover (e.g. a brochure) please count these pages seperately in the appropriate section.

Paper finish describes the surface or texture of a sheet of paper or cardstock. Finish affects the look and feel of the paper, but more importantly, it can impact printability and absorbency by dictating how the sheet will take ink.

If a particular paper finish is not here please add it in.
fields.Help Section 2 Text:
Whether a paper is coated or uncoated can affect its finish.

Coated paper has been coated with a surface sealant to impart certain qualities to the paper, including weight, surface gloss, smoothness or reduced ink absorbency. This allows for cleaner crisper printing, especially in photos, blends and fine details.

Uncoated paper stock is paper that has not been coated with a surface sealant. Inks dry by absorbing into the paper. This paper type can dull the colors that are printed. Uncoated papers comprise a vast number of paper types and are available in a variety of surfaces, both smooth and textured.
fields.Help Section 3 Text: Gloss paper has an incredibly high shine and a smooth tactile feel. It’s a popular choice for leaflets and flyers because it enhances colours.
fields.Help Section 4 Text: Satin paper has a lower gloss level than gloss paper, yet a higher gloss level than matte paper. Colors are sharp and vivid.
fields.Help Section 5 Text: Matte paper has a muted surface that refracts light subtly and evenly, reducing any glare. It also has a soft, textured feel to it.
fields.Help Section 6 Text: Silk paper has the smooth feel of glossy paper but without the shine.
fields.Help Section 7 Text: Wove paper also known as Smooth paper has a very smooth surface.
fields.Help Section 8 Text: Laid paper is created with textured lines on its surface. This finish is used mostly for business stationery elements, like letterhead, envelopes and business cards.
fields.Help Section 9 Text: Similar to a laid finish, this paper has textured lines on the surface of the sheet, but they are finer and more regular than those that appear on a laid finish stock. This paper is also used frequently for business stationery.

fields.Help Section 1 Text:
Paper weights are either offered in gsm (grams per square meter) or lbs (USA system). 

When specifying the weight in lbs you will also need to specify whether the paper is bond, book or cover paper.
fields.Help Section 2 Text: The weight range of standard office paper, used in your desktop laser printer or photocopier and would rarely be used for brochures.
fields.Help Section 3 Text: Commonly used for stationary paper for things such as letterheads and compliment slips.
fields.Help Section 4 Text: Heavier, more durable paper usually used for posters, leaflets, flyers and pages inside a book.
fields.Help Section 5 Text: This is the midway point between paper and card. It can be used for brochure covers and is great when used for more luxurious posters or quality double sided flyers.
fields.Help Section 6 Text: Moving away from paper, this is regarded as card (board) weights which can add a quality finish to a book if used as a cover.
fields.Help Section 7 Text: Usually the weights of a good business card. Some will use 300gsm, or less, for a business card but we do not recommend it. 350gsm can also be used as a cover for your book but it’s important to remember the stitching and folding implications of using heavy board as a cover.
fields.Help Section 8 Text: Some luxury business cards are printed on weights up to 1190gsm. Business cards would be considered thick and very good quality at above 400gsm.

fields.Help Section 1 Text:
The paper brand is whatever company manufactured and sold the paper. 

e.g. Sappi Magno Satin paper - the paper brand is Sappi.

If the paper brand is not in the dropdown please add it.

The paper name is the name of the particular paper.

e.g. Sappi Magno Satin paper - the paper name is Magno Satin.

If the paper name is not in the dropdown please add it in.

Spot colors are premixed colors that produce accurate color matches to solid elements within the artwork.

Process color printing is the active layering of colors to create artwork. Typically Cyan, Magenta, Yellow, and Black (CMYK) inks are stacked in dotted patterns at different angles to create a broad range of colors and images.
If a coating or finish has been applied to the paper please specify it here.
A varnish is a coating that can be printed on a press like ink is.
fields.Help Section 2 Text: The varnish is sprayed on to the paper / card in the same way as other varnishes. However, after spraying the card passes underneath UV lights which dries the varnish almost instantaneously.
fields.Help Section 3 Text: Encapsulation involves covering both sides of the printed sheet with plastic and securing it with a plastic border. This makes it watertight.
fields.Help Section 4 Text: Aqueous coating is a clear, fast-drying water-based coating that is used to protect printed pieces.
fields.Help Section 5 Text: Lamination Printing is the process of applying a thin layer of plastic to paper or card sheets to enhance and protect the printed matter.

fields.Help Section 1 Text: You can apply the varnish either as a process, which covers the entire print, or a spot varnish, which allows you to varnish only specific text, images or graphics on your printed piece. If you choose a spot varnish, a plate will be required to print, and artwork designating the areas you want the spot varnish to cover needs to be provided to your service provider.

This is the number of pages in the item which have been coated, please count the pages even if they are not printed on. If the item has a cover (e.g. a brochure) please count these pages seperately in the appropriate section.
Embellishments are the decorative details that make your printed pieces stand out from the rest.

The embossing process creates relief images and designs on paper and other materials. There are many embossing types, including blind emboss, registered emboss, combination emboss, glazing and scorching. This process works best on thicker paper stock.
fields.Help Section 2 Text: Debossing is the reverse process of embossing -- it creates lowered images or designs on paper by stamping them into the material. Just like embossing, this process also works well on thicker papers.
fields.Help Section 3 Text: Foil printing is a speciality printing process which uses heat, pressure and metallic paper (foil). This is used to create different shiny designs and graphics on various materials.

fields.Help Section 1 Text: This is the method used to cut special shapes (i.e. anything other than rectangle or square). It means you can create a custom shaped direct mailer, leaflet etc. Die cutting is also what is used to create a cut-out section in the middle of a brochure cover or packaging card.
The finished page size of a product is the dimensions of the finished product after all edge trimming.
Please specify the printing method used.
Was the artwork supplied for the print job or was it designed as part of the job?
Was a proof supplied as part of the job?
This is the width of the products footprint.
This is the depth of the products footprint.
This is the height of the product.
This is the total weight supported by the product. If the product is not meant to support anything please leave empty.
This is the area of the shelves which can be used to stock items.
Each item is made up of a combination of different materials, select the material used in the production of each item. Please ignore any small components such as screws.
Please include the mass of the material used to manufacture the particular item.
Please include the area of the material used to manufacture the particular item.
Select the product which is supported by the POS item. If the product is not in the list please add it in.
Enter the width of the product supported by the POS item.
Enter the depth of the product supported by the POS item.
Enter the height of the product supported by the POS item.
The quantity of the product which is supported by the POS item.
Select the apparel type. If the product is not in the list please add it in.
Select the size of the item. If the size is not there please add it in.
Enter the dry mass of a single item.
Please enter a printing method if there is one.
fields.Help Section 2 Text:
The screen printing method is ideal for printing high-quality t-shirt designs, because it guarantees ultimate replication of the design. 

Most companies that use the screen printing methods for mass production of t-shirt designs for your business. If you want a single or unique design for yourself, it may be impossible.

This method is suited for one color per screen. It is not ideal for super complex multi-color designs.
fields.Help Section 3 Text:
The Direct To Garment method is excellent for printing out complex and unique designs. It gives a soft feel on the hands when you touch the final design. The ink used doesn't create thick extra layers on the shirt, because it is thin.

You can end up with a low resolution design with dot patterns if you have an inferior textile printer. You can't use this method to create design for dark fabric, because the ink is thin and won't look well.

DTG is not very durable and the fabric may fade in a year or less.
fields.Help Section 4 Text:
Dye-Sublimation works well on light shirts or fabrics. It is expensive but the quality is generally high.

Dye-Sublimation is excellent for printing polyester shirts with minimal enduring designs. Dye-Sublimation is durable and high quality.

Dye-Sublimation is however unforgiving on cotton.
fields.Help Section 5 Text:
If you have small orders of shirt, it is economical to use the heat press printing.

If you are working with complex designs, then this method is ideal for you. However, it won't work well with dark fabrics because of its translucent dye.

fields.Help Section 1 Text: Select a material used in the product. If the material is not present please add it in.
Was the material made organically?
What percentage of the apparel is made from this material. The sum of the percentages of all materials used should be 100%.
Select where the material was manufactured.
Specify what quantity is being delivered to this location.
Specify the delivery address.
Select your shipping supplier. If your shipping supplier is not listed please add it in.
Select your shipping method. If you shipping method is not listed please add it in.
Specify the date on which the package was shipped.
Select any chemical consumables used. If the chemical type is not listed please add it in.
Select the brand of chemical used. If the brand is not listed please add it in.
Select the chemical name used. If the chemical name is not listed please add it in.
Select or enter the product code of the chemicals used.
Enter the amount of chemical used.
Please enter any additional information which will affect the quality, cost, environmental impact or social responsibility status of your product.
